instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115B: What is 820-3115B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT: What is PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT? PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT is the voltage rail for the backlight of the LCD screen. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
I have a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> here with no power and no green light on the charger

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present as is <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.23v, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are missing this is because <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is missing. Board is pulling only 13ma from the charger.  I'm guessing bad SMC.

Board was originally liquid damaged (can't remember exactly where as this was probably 2 years ago) and <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground internally in the board, I dug the board out to clear the short and ran a jumper and the board seemed to be working fine. Installed the board in a macbook and left it installing OSX overnight, came back in to morning to find the keyboard no longer worked, replaced <CHIP>U5701</CHIP> with no change and then decided it was a SMC issue (Can't remember why I thought this) and proceed to rip a pad off the only spare SMC I had so the board sat in a pile until recently when I had a spare SMC, reballed and installed this and still no keyboard.  Resoldered <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>, no change. Cleaned and reseated the keyboard ribbon only to find the macbook would no longer power on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
This is a bit confusing. You did replace the SMC on this board? With one with a ripped pad?

This is obviously SMC related. What is <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>?

As far as the keyboard issue goes, is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_PSOC</SIGNAL> present on pin 22 and 49 of <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
No, the SMC I eventually fitted had all it's pad's intact

<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> is 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3_PSOC</SIGNAL> won't be present as the board is no longer powering on

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Something isn't right with the SMC install. 

More flux and reflow it again. If it does not work, reball it or just grab a new one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
If the board doesn't turn on just after SMC replacing, then something wrong happened in this process.
But I'm not sure about this, as you also said
"Cleaned and reseated the keyboard ribbon only to find the macbook would no longer power on"
So test the board alone on the desk, no TP/KB, nor other device connected.
Just DC board and check for voltage on the coils.
Use <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR>/16 pads instead of power button.
See if you get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and steady <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>.
Also check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> and use original Apple 60/85W charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Yes the board did work after replacing the SMC, it only stopped working after I started looking into the keyboard issues again. I did try reflowing the SMC anyway which made no difference

With the bare board on the desk I am still getting 12.23v on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is a steady 3.44v. <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is 0.29v
I'm still powering the board off the bench supply as it turns out I don't have a working original magsafe 1 charger right now, I will borrow one form work tommrow and test it with that
Not sure which coils you mean?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
PCH will not start power sequence with low level at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>.
This is sign of incorrect charger, or SMC issue...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> is at 0.03v
The cable on my bench supply works fine on another macbook, looks like it is time to order a scrap board from china as I don't have any 3115 scrap boards that still have a SMC on them

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
OK,
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> was shorted to ground and L4901 had come off the board so I wasn't seeing a short on <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>, Removed and cleaned the SMC  and board both show no short now so I must have had shorted balls under the chip. Will reball it and report back

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
Reballed and reinstalled SMC and macbook now powers on fine.
Now back to the keyboard issue's Both the keyboard and trackpad work fine in EFI, neither work once the macbook has booted a OS

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> was missing on <TRANSISTOR>Q5701</TRANSISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R6961</RESISTOR> but was present on <RESISTOR>R5071</RESISTOR>. Just ran a jumper all the way across the board and now the KB and TP work fine in the OS.
Still confused on how I had the macbook booting before when I apparently had a short under the SMC but at least it is working now.
